metadata.case_name: Writ Petition Nos. 34 of 1974 and 959 of 1973 and Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974
metadata.case_number: Writ Petitions Nos. 34 of 1974 and 959 of 1973; Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974

facts.text: Petitioners in Writ Petitions engaged in purchase and export of Cinchona products between 1966 and 1971; submitted tenders which were accepted and entered into contracts with State Government for large sums.
Petitioners submitted tenders on 15th February 1973 and 4th December 1973; since December 1970, all offers rejected though in most cases highest.

Sales Committee on 21 January 1971 resolved not to deal with petitioners' firm till cleared of charges of malpractices, based on secret letter from Collector of Customs, Calcutta, about involvement in malpractices under investigation.
Petitioners came to know of resolution at Sales Committee meeting on 4 December 1973; State could not produce original resolution.
Petitioners challenged charges and cases under Foreign Exchange Regulations Act in Calcutta High Court in Writ Petition No. 959 of 1973, which is pending.
Respondent in Civil Appeal No. 318 of 1974 on approved list of Director General, Supplies and Disposals since 1942; last renewal on 5 June 1963 for three years.
Reports received against respondent regarding shortage of timber; Special Police Establishment took account books in August 1964.
Departmental enquiry against store-keeper and store-holder in Bombay Telephone Workshop; suspended in December 1964.
Department put respondent's name on black list on 4 December 1965.
Suspended employees dismissed on 1 June 1967; High Court set aside dismissals on 3 August 1972.
Respondent applied for return of account books in January 1968; ordered returned in March 1968.
Respondent filed Writ Petition in Bombay High Court on 20 January 1969; allowed on 12 January 1973 setting aside blacklisting; State's appeal dismissed.

legal_issues.text: Whether a person who is put on the black list by the State Government is entitled to a notice to be heard before the name is put on the black list.

petitioner_arguments.text: There is discrimination and lack of fair play at the sale; entitled to receive the same treatment and to be given the same chance as anybody else for the purchase of Cinchona.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner not entitled to mandamus as sales contractual; no right to acceptance of tender; attitude not discriminatory but pending proceedings under Foreign Exchange Regulation Act should be adjudicated first.

Government can choose any person for contract; insist on dealing with persons of trust and integrity; black-listing is internal and confidential step; no rights under Articles 14, 19, 21 to compel contract.

court_reasoning.text: State has right to trade but duty to observe equality; blacklisting deprives person of equality of opportunity in public contract; affects legitimate interest or expectation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order of blacklisting has effect of depriving a person of equality of opportunity in matter of public contract.

court_reasoning.text: Blacklisting involves civil consequences, casts slur, creates barrier; State must act fairly without discrimination; fundamentals of fair play require opportunity to represent before blacklisting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty to act fairly includes giving opportunity to represent case before putting on blacklist.

court_reasoning.text: Activities of Government have public element requiring fairness and equality; reputation part of personality, blacklisting tarnishes it; exclusion from dealing prevents lawful trade.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Person concerned should be given opportunity to represent his case before put on blacklist.

holdings.text: Person entitled to opportunity to represent before blacklisting; authorities to give opportunity to petitioners whether name should be put on blacklist or not.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art. 32; blacklisting affects rights under Arts. 14,19,21; executive power under Art. 298 subject to Part III.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulations Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Pending proceedings against petitioners for alleged violations; blacklisting based on such proceedings.

outcome.summary: Writ petitions succeed; authorities directed to give opportunity to petitioners to represent before blacklisting, without affecting pending Calcutta High Court proceedings. Civil Appeal dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Opportunity to be heard before blacklisting; writs allowed, blacklisting set aside in appeal.
outcome.costs: Parties will pay and bear their own costs.

key_quotes.text: Fundamentals of fair play require that the person concerned should be given an opportunity to represent his case before he is put on the blacklist.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on natural justice in blacklisting.

key_quotes.text: The order of black-listing, has the effect of depriving a person of equality of opportunity in the matter of public contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Blacklisting tarnishes ones reputation. Exclusion of a member of the public from dealing with a State in sales transactions has the effect of preventing him from purchasing and doing a lawful trade.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights civil consequences and right to livelihood.
